chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of Morton's neuroma and a brief discussion of options that may be available in secondary care if referral is required.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Management of Morton's neuroma
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person:
    • To avoid high heels, and shoes with a constricting toe box or thin soles to reduce pressure on the forefoot.
    • To use a metatarsal pad: 
      • These are available over-the-counter.
      • The pad should be placed just proximal to the metatarsal heads to reduce pressure from the nerve.
  • Consider offering nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs if necessary. For more information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
  • Offer written information on Morton's neuroma, such as that available from the NHS.  
  • If symptoms persist despite 3 months of footwear modifications and using metatarsal pads:
    • Refer the person to an orthotist for a metatarsal dome orthotic.
    • If referral to orthotics is not available, or if symptoms persist despite a trial of an orthotic device:
      • Refer to an orthopaedic surgeon with a special interest in the foot, a musculoskeletal clinic, or a podiatric surgeon (depending on local policy and service provision) for consideration of specialist treatments such as corticosteroid injection or surgery.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist treatments
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Treatments that may be offered in secondary care include:
    • Corticosteroid injection [Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010; Adams et al, 2011; Peters et al, 2011; Thomas et al, 2009a; Pomeroy et al, 2015].
    • Neurectomy of the involved interdigital nerve and neuroma  [Thomas et al, 2009a; Adams, 2010; Nazarko, 2011; Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014].
      • The affected portion of nerve is removed.
    • Decompression of the interdigital nerve by deep transverse metatarsal ligament release, with or without neurolysis [Briggs, 2006; Thomas et al, 2009a; Nazarko, 2011; Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014]. 
      • Compression of the nerve is reduced by dividing the deep transverse inter-metatarsal ligament.
    • Guided alcohol injections [Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010; Peters et al, 2011].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Footwear modification and metatarsal pads
  • Expert opinion based on review articles [Woodburn and Helliwell, 2009; Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010; Adams et al, 2011; Peters et al, 2011], a clinical guideline [Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014], a clinical consensus document [Thomas et al, 2009a], and evidence from two case series [Bennett et al, 1995; Saygi et al, 2005] is that footwear modifications and metatarsal pads should be first-line treatment. 
  • The recommendation to avoid shoes with high heels or a constricting toe box is also based on expert opinion from guidelines issued by NHS Scotland [NHS Scotland, 2005] and expert opinion from a review article [Baquie et al, 2009]. The recommendation to avoid thin-soled shoes is based on the expert opinion of a previous reviewer of this CKS topic.
  • A Cochrane systematic review found insufficient evidence to confirm the effectiveness of supinatory insoles for Morton's neuroma [Thomson, 2004]. Supinatory insoles are not mentioned as a current treatment option in a clinical practice guideline [Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014].
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • CKS identified no evidence to support the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in the treatment of Morton's neuroma. However their use is supported by expert opinion in review articles [Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010; Nazarko, 2011; Peters et al, 2011; Pomeroy et al, 2015] and previous reviewers of this CKS topic consider that they may have limited use in some people. 
Written information
  • This recommendation is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Referral following conservative treatment
  • CKS found no evidence on the timescale of referral if conservative treatment is not effective. The recommendation to try footwear modifications and use metatarsal pads for 3 months prior to referral is based on the expert opinion of previous reviewers of this CKS topic.
Referral to an orthotist for a metatarsal dome orthotic
  • The recommendation to refer to an orthotist for a metatarsal dome orthotic if footwear modifications and metatarsal pads have not been successful is based on expert opinion in review articles [Woodburn and Helliwell, 2009; Adams, 2010] and expert opinion from previous reviewers of this CKS topic.
Referral to an orthopaedic surgeon with a special interest in the foot, a musculoskeletal clinic, or a podiatric surgeon
  • The recommendation to refer people with persistent symptoms for consideration of specialist treatments is based on expert opinion in review articles [Adams, 2010; Peters et al, 2011], NHS Scotland guidelines [NHS Scotland, 2005], and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
